JAY HARRIERS WIN
FROM CATHOLIC U.
Brooklander's First Attempt
At Cross-Country
Running
SCORE, 1 5 - 4 0
First Perfect Score Made In
Last Four Years
Saturday the Johns Hopkins harriers ran a perfect race to beat the
Catholic University cross-country
team by a score of 15-40.
This score, aocording to Captain "Bob" Kelly, is the first perfect
score made by the Hopkins hill and
dales in at least four years. Several times the team has won by a
nearly perfect score, but this is the
first time in recent years that the
Jays have finished five men in the
first five places.
Difficult Course

The race was run over the Catholic University course which is just
outside of Washington. The course
while not as difficult as the Homewood five mile stretch, is considered
a very bad grind. It is over country roads and winds up and down
several very bad hills. With the
hard running of the course, the poor
marking of the directions added to
the difficulty of the meet.
Because of the insufficiency of
guiding signs Schiebel ran off the
main road twice, being directed
back both times before he had run
more than a half a mile out of his
way. The • first time he went off,
Kelly also lost the track as did Packard, but the second time he left the
course he was alone and continued
running until called back by Kelly.
Jays Take First Five Places

Although he did get off the
course and ran extra distances,
Schiebel managed to beat Kelly by
a single pace to the finish. Emerson
finished in third place, Packard
came fourth, Miller _ran fifth.
Hickey, of Catholic University,
placed sixth, Waters came in next,
then Rinandot of Catholic U. placed
before Reedis of Hopkins crossed
the line. Sugerman followed several Washingtonians to finish in the
thirteenth place. He was followed
by other maroon harriers.
Catholic U. Has New Team

Although the defeat was so crushing the Catholic U. team is not as
poor as the result indicates. This
meet was the first contest of the
type ever held by the Brooklanders.
They have just this season taken to
the sport and three weeks ago began to get their men in shape. Because of this lack of experience
and the lack of support offered by
the students, the team did not show
up well, however, according to report, the prospects for the coming
seasons are good. Their runners,
with knowledge of the harrier tactics, will be a match for any team.
Their schedule this year is hard
for a new team. Next week, the
second meet of the sason, the Maroon runners will oppose the Maryland harriers, then the week after
they will meet St. Johns' strong hill
and dale team.
Next week the Hopkins team was
to have journeyed to take part in
the Middle Atlantic Cross-Country
meet, but owing to the inelligibility
of Schiebel and Packard it is rumored that this trip will be called off.
If this is done the St. Johns' meet,
scheduled for the middle of next
Week, will be moved forward to
Saturday and will be run so that
the race will end. between the halves
of the football game.

THE JOHNS HOPKINS NEWS-LETTER, NOVEMBER 8, 1929

1929 HULLABALOO
TO HODL DANCE
The 1929 Hullabaloo incurred a debt on their issue,
and are planning to hold a
benefit dance Thanksgiving
night at the Southern, Hotel.
It is hoped that this will be
a victory dance. The Cotillion Board had planned for
that evening, but it is planned
that they consolidate with the
Hullabaloon, whereby the Cotilion Board will receive all the
profits left after the Hullabaloo bill is paid. The Alumni
Association, which holds an
annual reunion Thanksgiving
night has promised to hold it
at the Southern, in order to
aid the Hullabaloo. The Varsity Club will also be represented at the dance.

Near the end of the course in Wyman's Park there is a very steep,

"Jay hill-and-vale men." R. 0. T.

maps add various and sundry comments.

Officers Elected At
Cane Club Meeting
The Cane Club held a meeting on
Tuesday, November 5, at 12:20 in
the Barn. Due to the fact that
many of its officers did not return
this year the club held an election
to fill their vacancies.
Baldwin Street was elected president to succeed John Deets. Henry
Houston succeeded Addison Reise
as vice-president. Hammond was
elected master of ceremonies. Stewart Lee Smith and Carey Seward,
as previously elected retained their
offices of treasurer and secretary respectively.

SENIOR CLASS TO
MEET FRIDAY
There will be a meeting of
the Senior Class Friday, November 15, according to Warring, president of the Class.
The purpose of the meeting
will be the ratification of the
solution, offered by last year's
Junior Class officers for filling the vacancies in the position of editor-in-chief of the
Hullabaloon. As each Senior
has a personal interest in the
Annual, it is his duty to be
present at this meeting. The
meeting will be held at 12:30
in the C. E. Hall immediately
following the class picture to
be taken on Gilman steps.

Well, another school year, a la Hopkins, has begun. To be exact, one month of it is gone. The freshmen have been pledged,
and the fraters are dusting off the paddles. And although the
campus itself has, within these last few years, been reformed, so
that a freshman has no longer to fear for his nethers, the fraternities still are existing uncivilized, savage and primitive.
Let us, then, give thanks, each to his own god, that these groups
have not yet fallen before the pernicious preachments of our most
holy student council. Barren of paddles our canonical campus may
be, but—aha, Mr. Hall—those whoassume the pin stil assume
the angle!

To the Hopkins student of other years, the campus has undergone a great change Mostly responsible is that hugh pile of
masonry, the new physics building, Rowland Hall to be, nee
"bricklayers' delight." Squatting beside the quadrangle, its massive bulk, when viewed from the lower walk, can make even a
sophomore feel small. Which is something—so I should term it—
considerable!

And while I'm on the subject, let me relate a little conversation
I managed to eavsdrop the other evening. Mr. .Somebody and
his handicap were taking an evening stroll on the campus.
Now I never like to speak disparagingly about the lady's figure,
but if this gentleman loved his wife he certainly loved a lot. To
recall my earlier figure of speech, he had a big handicap. I
wouldn't have called her elephantine, of course, but—well, let's
say sizeable. Well, anyhow, the pair of them stood there gawking
at the building a few minutes, and then she turned to him and
said: "It's awfully nice, Henry, but the rear of it looks so big."

A. H. FETTING
MANUFACTURING JEWELRY CO.

EDITORIALS

And so Levering Hall, the Y. M. C. A.'s prodigal son, has
made good! Contrary to many beliefs and predictions, a good
rousing hymn hasn't been heard to emanate from its portals yet.
No candles have been lit, and I am still trying to find the altar.
There isn't a stained glass in the place, and in lieu of incense and
pews are smoking cigarettes and arm-chairs. Of course, a lot of
Bibles were distributed on registration day, but they were of the
freshman variety.

who took English Composition I
± spent ten or fifteen minutes in making the "Library Tour" as Dr.
French used to call it. Unfortunately, with the passing of that ancient
and time-honored course, the underclassmen are far too apt to forget
that the University has a library. For most, the reserve shelf is the
boundary across which they seldom step and the required books limit
the extent of their reading. Such a state of affairs is, indeed, regrettable,
for half one's education can be gotten from books off the beaten track,
and much of the pleasure of study comes from pursuing the interesting sidelights to original sources in unsuspected books.

Impossible as it is to allow a horde of mere undergraduates to wander through the stacks in search of volumes of ancient lore, the catalogue should serve as a partial substitute. Amid the maze of cards
which one must wade through, are many and many a title which should
attract the curious book-lover in his quest for buried knowledge. The
catalogue is much like a grab-bag. You put your hand in, but never
can tell what is coming out. Sometimes the selected volume is full of
hitherto hidden treasures. From the brief material on a card, one must
judge whether that is the best source for the desired material. Only
when the book comes from the stacks can we tell whether our grab has
been successful or not.
The intricacies of the card catalogue are greater than the average
uninformed person would suspect. It would be a wise plan if every
student should have a chance to follow a book through the cataloguing
process. A corps of trained cataloguers must handle every book entering the library before it can be put on the shelves in the place where it

will be most useful to the largest number of students. That is why the
catalogue becomes a useful source of information.
Perhaps, in addition to taking psychological tests, incoming freshmen will be required to make the grand tour of the library, so that

within the shortest possible time, its shelves will serve them to the
greatest advantage. Dr. French, as an interested friend of the undergraduates and as Librarian of the University, should revive at least this
much of "English Comp.

FOOTBALL OR CIRCUS?
understand that the R. 0. T. C. may be asked

stage a
WEdemonstration for the benefit of the spectators at thetoMaryland
game on Thanksgiving Day. While we are by no means pacifistic,
such a display is not to be desired. Without casting any reflection on
the Hopkins unit, the latter certainly is in no position to imitate either
the West Point cadets or the Annapolis midshipmen, whose drills on
the football field have become famous. The R. 0. T. C. here does not
want to make itself ridiculous in the eyes of the people of Baltimore
who may turn out to witness the Hopkins-Maryland contest. And yet,
that would inevitably happen were the unit to engage in any such

attempt. In the first place, our "army" is so small it would look lost in
the bowl, and to those who had seen the midshipmen earlier in the
season, the sight of a mere handful of khaki-clad boys who had not
yet learned to march with precision would appear ludicrous. Hopkins
is by no means an athletic college. Why try to ape other colleges whose
teams are really an important part of their institutions? Football io us
a sport and we have no reason to put on a show for the benefit of

is

spectators who pay to see a football game and expect a three-ring circus
besides. We trust that the R. 0. T. C. unit will refuse to lend its aid
to any such publicity scheme.
P. W. S.

One of the favorite themes of NEWS-LETTER columnists, and
also of undergraduates who wish to break into print by writing letters to the editor, is the rear of the new Art Museum. Displaying
a marked human characteristic, the Museum puts up a very fine
front, hoping that a much less impressive rear will go unnoticed.
It probably would, if only it didn't stare the Hopkins campus
smack in the face. Hence the complaints of Hopkins men who
consider it a blemish on the beauty of fair Homewood.

Vernon 4300
•

Here is one, however, who begs to—no, does differ! The red
brick, I think, of the Art Museum's rear blends quite well with the
Georgian style; the dazzling (?) white of the facade would most
surely clash with the Hopkins architectural scheme. And the
large arched window in the back of the building is perfectly concordant. If you are doubtful, take a peek at the one in the great
hall of Levering. Or, going to the other extreme, at the doorway
of the old Barn.

Getting back to Levering Hall, the free Water in the cafeteria
is proving tremendously popular. One cent is not much, but the
penny-cup machines in Gilman have never exactly met with
hearty approval. The average person doesn't like to complain over
a penny—it makes him appear too niggardly—but all the same
most of us have wondered at times why the cups couldn't be had
gratis. Of course, water that comes in bottles costs something,
and the cups probably help to pay for that. Which, after all,
really makes it fair. But the usual dilemma is that one never
seems to have a thirst and penny simultaneously. Of course, the
machines will operate with a nickel or dime, and I can even remember certain rare occasions when such coins were used; but
take the average fellow—well, his father is no millionaire! Thus
it is that, to the penniless, Gilman Hall is a rather arid region.
Almost a mild form of Prohibition!
But now, as I started to say, that is all changed. Water, cooled
by Frigidaire, flows freely in Levering's cafeteria. And thirsty,
thrifty students (it's a big temptation to say something about the
Scotch here), will do well to take heed.

The la-test Black and Blue Jay features (?) a new column on
its last page, entitled "Passin' Out." As much as one dislikes to
discourage struggling, ambitious, young columnists, the best one
can say of it is that the sooner it passes—why, the better! Its
author, or authors, most judiciously remains anonymous, but

Vol. XXXIV, No. 12

JAY HARRIERS WIN
FROM CATHOLIC U.
Brooklander's First Attempt
At Cross-Country
Running
SCORE, 1 5 - 4 0
First Perfect Score Made In
Last Four Years
Saturday the Johns Hopkins harriers ran a perfect race to beat the
Catholic University cross-country
team by a score of 15-40.
This score, aocording to Captain "Bob" Kelly, is the first perfect
score made by the Hopkins hill and
dales in at least four years. Several times the team has won by a
nearly perfect score, but this is the
first time in recent years that the
Jays have finished five men in the
first five places.
Difficult Course

The race was run over the Catholic University course which is just
outside of Washington. The course
while not as difficult as the Homewood five mile stretch, is considered
a very bad grind. It is over country roads and winds up and down
several very bad hills. With the
hard running of the course, the poor
marking of the directions added to
the difficulty of the meet.
Because of the insufficiency of
guiding signs Schiebel ran off the
main road twice, being directed
back both times before he had run
more than a half a mile out of his
way. The • first time he went off,
Kelly also lost the track as did Packard, but the second time he left the
course he was alone and continued
running until called back by Kelly.
Jays Take First Five Places

Although he did get off the
course and ran extra distances,
Schiebel managed to beat Kelly by
a single pace to the finish. Emerson
finished in third place, Packard
came fourth, Miller _ran fifth.
Hickey, of Catholic University,
placed sixth, Waters came in next,
then Rinandot of Catholic U. placed
before Reedis of Hopkins crossed
the line. Sugerman followed several Washingtonians to finish in the
thirteenth place. He was followed
by other maroon harriers.
Catholic U. Has New Team

Although the defeat was so crushing the Catholic U. team is not as
poor as the result indicates. This
meet was the first contest of the
type ever held by the Brooklanders.
They have just this season taken to
the sport and three weeks ago began to get their men in shape. Because of this lack of experience
and the lack of support offered by
the students, the team did not show
up well, however, according to report, the prospects for the coming
seasons are good. Their runners,
with knowledge of the harrier tactics, will be a match for any team.
Their schedule this year is hard
for a new team. Next week, the
second meet of the sason, the Maroon runners will oppose the Maryland harriers, then the week after
they will meet St. Johns' strong hill
and dale team.
Next week the Hopkins team was
to have journeyed to take part in
the Middle Atlantic Cross-Country
meet, but owing to the inelligibility
of Schiebel and Packard it is rumored that this trip will be called off.
If this is done the St. Johns' meet,
scheduled for the middle of next
Week, will be moved forward to
Saturday and will be run so that
the race will end. between the halves
of the football game.

1929 HULLABALOO
TO HODL DANCE
The 1929 Hullabaloo incurred a debt on their issue,
and are planning to hold a
benefit dance Thanksgiving
night at the Southern, Hotel.
It is hoped that this will be
a victory dance. The Cotillion Board had planned for
that evening, but it is planned
that they consolidate with the
Hullabaloon, whereby the Cotilion Board will receive all the
profits left after the Hullabaloo bill is paid. The Alumni
Association, which holds an
annual reunion Thanksgiving
night has promised to hold it
at the Southern, in order to
aid the Hullabaloo. The Varsity Club will also be represented at the dance.

Well, another school year, a la Hopkins, has begun. To be exact, one month of it is gone. The freshmen have been pledged,
and the fraters are dusting off the paddles. And although the
campus itself has, within these last few years, been reformed, so
that a freshman has no longer to fear for his nethers, the fraternities still are existing uncivilized, savage and primitive.
Let us, then, give thanks, each to his own god, that these groups
have not yet fallen before the pernicious preachments of our most
holy student council. Barren of paddles our canonical campus may
be, but—aha, Mr. Hall—those whoassume the pin stil assume
the angle!

To the Hopkins student of other years, the campus has undergone a great change Mostly responsible is that hugh pile of
masonry, the new physics building, Rowland Hall to be, nee
"bricklayers' delight." Squatting beside the quadrangle, its massive bulk, when viewed from the lower walk, can make even a
sophomore feel small. Which is something—so I should term it—
considerable!

And while I'm on the subject, let me relate a little conversation
I managed to eavsdrop the other evening. Mr. .Somebody and
his handicap were taking an evening stroll on the campus.
Now I never like to speak disparagingly about the lady's figure,
but if this gentleman loved his wife he certainly loved a lot. To
recall my earlier figure of speech, he had a big handicap. I
wouldn't have called her elephantine, of course, but—well, let's
say sizeable. Well, anyhow, the pair of them stood there gawking
at the building a few minutes, and then she turned to him and
said: "It's awfully nice, Henry, but the rear of it looks so big."

And so Levering Hall, the Y. M. C. A.'s prodigal son, has
made good! Contrary to many beliefs and predictions, a good
rousing hymn hasn't been heard to emanate from its portals yet.
No candles have been lit, and I am still trying to find the altar.
There isn't a stained glass in the place, and in lieu of incense and
pews are smoking cigarettes and arm-chairs. Of course, a lot of
Bibles were distributed on registration day, but they were of the
freshman variety.

who took English Composition I
± spent ten or fifteen minutes in making the "Library Tour" as Dr.
French used to call it. Unfortunately, with the passing of that ancient
and time-honored course, the underclassmen are far too apt to forget
that the University has a library. For most, the reserve shelf is the
boundary across which they seldom step and the required books limit
the extent of their reading. Such a state of affairs is, indeed, regrettable,
for half one's education can be gotten from books off the beaten track,
and much of the pleasure of study comes from pursuing the interesting sidelights to original sources in unsuspected books.

Impossible as it is to allow a horde of mere undergraduates to wander through the stacks in search of volumes of ancient lore, the catalogue should serve as a partial substitute. Amid the maze of cards
which one must wade through, are many and many a title which should
attract the curious book-lover in his quest for buried knowledge. The
catalogue is much like a grab-bag. You put your hand in, but never
can tell what is coming out. Sometimes the selected volume is full of
hitherto hidden treasures. From the brief material on a card, one must
judge whether that is the best source for the desired material. Only
when the book comes from the stacks can we tell whether our grab has
been successful or not.
The intricacies of the card catalogue are greater than the average
uninformed person would suspect. It would be a wise plan if every
student should have a chance to follow a book through the cataloguing
process. A corps of trained cataloguers must handle every book entering the library before it can be put on the shelves in the place where it

will be most useful to the largest number of students. That is why the
catalogue becomes a useful source of information.
Perhaps, in addition to taking psychological tests, incoming freshmen will be required to make the grand tour of the library, so that

within the shortest possible time, its shelves will serve them to the
greatest advantage. Dr. French, as an interested friend of the undergraduates and as Librarian of the University, should revive at least this
much of "English Comp.

One of the favorite themes of NEWS-LETTER columnists, and
also of undergraduates who wish to break into print by writing letters to the editor, is the rear of the new Art Museum. Displaying
a marked human characteristic, the Museum puts up a very fine
front, hoping that a much less impressive rear will go unnoticed.
It probably would, if only it didn't stare the Hopkins campus
smack in the face. Hence the complaints of Hopkins men who
consider it a blemish on the beauty of fair Homewood.

Vernon 4300
•

Here is one, however, who begs to—no, does differ! The red
brick, I think, of the Art Museum's rear blends quite well with the
Georgian style; the dazzling (?) white of the facade would most
surely clash with the Hopkins architectural scheme. And the
large arched window in the back of the building is perfectly concordant. If you are doubtful, take a peek at the one in the great
hall of Levering. Or, going to the other extreme, at the doorway
of the old Barn.

Getting back to Levering Hall, the free Water in the cafeteria
is proving tremendously popular. One cent is not much, but the
penny-cup machines in Gilman have never exactly met with
hearty approval. The average person doesn't like to complain over
a penny—it makes him appear too niggardly—but all the same
most of us have wondered at times why the cups couldn't be had
gratis. Of course, water that comes in bottles costs something,
and the cups probably help to pay for that. Which, after all,
really makes it fair. But the usual dilemma is that one never
seems to have a thirst and penny simultaneously. Of course, the
machines will operate with a nickel or dime, and I can even remember certain rare occasions when such coins were used; but
take the average fellow—well, his father is no millionaire! Thus
it is that, to the penniless, Gilman Hall is a rather arid region.
Almost a mild form of Prohibition!
But now, as I started to say, that is all changed. Water, cooled
by Frigidaire, flows freely in Levering's cafeteria. And thirsty,
thrifty students (it's a big temptation to say something about the
Scotch here), will do well to take heed.

The la-test Black and Blue Jay features (?) a new column on
its last page, entitled "Passin' Out." As much as one dislikes to
discourage struggling, ambitious, young columnists, the best one
can say of it is that the sooner it passes—why, the better! Its
author, or authors, most judiciously remains anonymous, but
whatever virtues he may have humility is not one of them. On the
contrary, mind you! He has the audacity to pose beside the justly
famous and incomparable Bosco! Such cocky precocity! "Do
you remember Bosco?" he asks. Yes, we must confess, all too
well! Especially when reading that strained, abortioned bilge that
"Passin' Out" mistakes for clevelness.
0 Spirit of Bosco—ora pro nobis!

The Sophs at Haverford are "all
wet." At any rate, they were last
week when they had their photographs taken in a drenching rain.
The Jolly Juniors became even jollier than usual and even the Solemn
Seniors broke into laughter while
watching the unfortunate second
year men try to look cheerful in
spite of what was happening to the
crease in their trousers. But the
Sophs could see nothing funny in
the proceedings; they were merely
pathetic.
